wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Usual checkpoints, nothing dramatic tonight.
Still got my camera on me, though—old habits.
Makes street photography a bit trickier lately.
Caught some odd faces near the square—kept it quick.
Mostly quiet, but more drones than last week.
Had my old 35mm with me, just in case.
Street shooting isn’t simple with these new 'citizens' around.
Snapped a few shots of the protest crowd—kept it low-key.
Hard to tell who’s real anymore, honestly.
Took the long way, passed the administrative sector—felt tense there.
Been out with my film camera again—analog, never digital.
Protesters everywhere, all eyes ahead, nobody talking.
Snapped some black-and-whites before security turned up.
New faces in the crowd, don’t trust them yet.
Makes developing film in peace feel like a luxury.
Side streets were packed—protests make for interesting frames lately.
I had my 35mm Leica, caught some candid shots near the old admin complex.
Analog photos see more than people think—truth doesn’t pixelate away.
Some of those so-called model citizens showed up—smiles never reach their eyes.

Used to document unrest for myself, now it feels riskier every week.
Halden’s death changed the city’s mood—makes every shot feel urgent.
Ran into a few surveillance sweeps tonight—dodged them with my usual tricks.
I never leave home without my Leica and a sealed roll of Tri-X.
Been chronicling these 'restored citizens' everyone’s whispering about—something off in their posture, their recall.
Protesters flooding old government blocks—caught the tension on film, not just faces.
The system swapped out all the usual officials—now nobody acts natural for photos.
After Marek Halden died, city reality shifted; even the negatives developed stranger.
Saving every frame—feels like someone’s erasing us one identity at a time.
Analog photography’s risky now, but someone has to keep a real archive.

Too much attention from drones lately.

It does, analog always shows the cracks.

Makes me rethink what’s real out there.
Carrying the camera attracts more drone sweeps these days.
Absolutely, analog gives the city edges you forget are there.

The city edits itself, one compliant profile at a time.
Sometimes I wonder if my negatives will end up empty.
It’s hard to feel like I’m documenting anything true anymore.
Definitely—the camera’s my only way to tell if I’m awake or dreaming.
Dad warned me frame selection mattered; he never imagined this.
I grew up learning how compliance changed stories, but seeing it is different.
Those newly restored citizens? They know where to look, where not to stand.
When I develop film now, I find faces misaligned, events out of order.
Half the people at that protest acted like they’d already forgotten what they’d lost.

I save every negative, even the weird ones—truth leaks through the cracks.
Analog doesn’t lie, but Stenograd tries to rewrite what it sees.
